title: About Me
text:
Short Bio
I am a first-year postgraduate student in Applied Mathematics at Mehran University of Engineering and Technology, Jamshoro (Pakistan).
I completed my undergraduate studies in Mathematics at the same university under the supervision of Dr. Sania Qureshi.
Alongside my formal studies, I am independently learning pure mathematics.
I created this website to share my ideas, notes, and important material related to various areas of Pure and Applied Mathematics.

title: Introduction of Numbers
text: This section is taken from the first part of the book titled Calculus by Michael Spivak, 4th edition.

title: Introduction of Numbers
text:
1. Basic Properties of Numbers
In this section we shall look at some of the basic properties of numbers, that are listed below:

P1) (Associative law of addition)
If \(a,b,c\) are any numbers, then \(a+(b+c) = (a+b)+c\).
P2) (Existence of additive identity)
If \(a\) is any number, then \(a+0 = 0+a = a\).
P3) (Existence of additive inverse)
For any number \(a\), there exists \(-a\) such that \(a + (-a) = 0\).
P4) (Commutative law of addition)
If \(a,b\) are any numbers, then \(a+b = b+a\).
P5) (Associative law of multiplication)
If \(a,b,c\) are any numbers, then \(a(bc) = (ab)c\).
P6) (Multiplicative identity)
\(a \cdot 1 = 1 \cdot a = a\), and \(1 \ne 0\).
P7) (Multiplicative inverse)
For \(a \ne 0\), there exists \(a^{-1}\) such that \(a a^{-1} = 1\).
P8) (Commutative law of multiplication)
\(ab = ba\).
P9) (Distributive law)
\(a(b+c) = ab + ac\).







ImportantProposition 1.1.1



For any numbers \(a\) and \(b\), the following holds:

\(a \cdot 0 = 0\)
\((-a)\cdot b = -(a\cdot b)\)
\((-a)\cdot (-b) = ab\)









TipProof





Show proof

For (a), notice \(a\cdot 0= a\cdot (0+0)=a\cdot 0+a\cdot 0\) therefore we have \(a\cdot 0=0\). For (b), observe that \((-a)\cdot b +ab= ((-a)+a)\cdot b=0\) using (a). Similarly (c) follows using previous two statements.




P10) For every number \(a\), exactly one of the following holds:

\(a = 0\)

\(a\) is in \(P\)

\(-a\) is in \(P\)

where \(P\) denotes the set of all positive numbers.
P11) (Closure under addition)
If \(a,b \in P\), then \(a+b \in P\).
P12) (Closure under multiplication)
If \(a,b \in P\), then \(a \cdot b \in P\).







NoteDefinition 1.1.2



Let \(a\) and \(b\) are any numbers, then the following hold:

\(a>b\) if \(a-b\in P\),
\(a<b\) if \(b>a\),
\(a\geq b\) if \(a>b\) or \(a=b\),
\(a\leq b\) if \(a<b\) or \(a=b\).









NoteDefinition 1.1.3



For any number \(a\), we define absolute value as following: \[
    |a|:=
    \begin{cases}
        a,& a\geq 0,\\
        -a,&a\leq 0.
    \end{cases}
    \]








ImportantTheorem 1.1.4 (Triangle Inequality)



For any numbers \(a\) and \(b\), we have \(|a+b|\leq |a|+|b|\).








TipProof





Show proof

We shall use the definition \(|a|:=\sqrt{a^2}\) for any number \(a\), and the fact that \(a\leq |a|\). So for any numbers \(a\) and \(b\), we have \(ab\leq |ab|=|a||b|\). Then \[ |a+b|^2 = (a+b)^2 = a^2 +2ab+ b^2 \leq |a|^2 +2|ab|+|b|^2 = (|a|+|b)^2.\] Hence it is easy to conclude \(|a+b|\leq |a|+|b|\).









WarningExercise



Prove the Schwarz Inequality: \[
    x_1y_1+x_2y_2\leq \sqrt{x_1^2+x_2^2}\cdot \sqrt{y_1^2+y_2^2}.
    \]


Hint

Show that \((x_1^2+x_2^2)(y_1^2+y_2^2)\geq (x_1y_1+x_2y_2)^2\) and complete the proof.
